query.result:
1 It appeared before me with the wings open 2 the beautiful image that in the sweet enjoyment 3 happily made the souls united;
4 it appeared each one a small tap in which 5 ray of sun burned so ignited, 6 that in my eyes it refracted him.

7 And that which I must portray extended, 8 never carried voice, nor wrote with ink, 9 nor was ever comprehended by fantasy;
10 for I saw and also heard speak the beak, 11 and sound in the voice “I” and “mine,” 12 when it was in the concept and “we” and “ours.”

13 And began: «To be just and pious 14 I am here exalted to that glory 15 that does not allow itself to be overcome by desire;
16 and on earth I left my memory 17 so made, that the people there evil 18 commend it, but do not follow the story».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
19 Così un sol calor di molte brage 20 si fa sentir, come di molti amori 21 usciva solo un suon di quella image.
query.result: 19 Thus a single heat of many flames 20 is felt, as from many loves 21 came forth only one sound from that image.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
22 Ond’ io appresso: «O perpetüi fiori 23 de l’etterna letizia, che pur uno 24 parer mi fate tutti vostri odori,
25 solvetemi, spirando, il gran digiuno 26 che lungamente m’ha tenuto in fame, 27 non trovandoli in terra cibo alcuno.
query.result:
22 And I drew near, saying: “O perpetual flowers 23 of eternal joy, that all one 24 you make me seem with all your scents,
25 release me, breathing, from the great fast 26 that has long held me in hunger, 27 not finding any food on earth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
28 Ben so io che, se ’n cielo altro reame 29 la divina giustizia fa suo specchio, 30 che ’l vostro non l’apprende con velame.
query.result: 28 Well I know that, if in heaven another realm 29 divine justice makes its mirror, 30 that yours does not learn it with covering.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
31 Sapete come attento io m’apparecchio 32 ad ascoltar; sapete qual è quello 33 dubbio che m’è digiun cotanto vecchio».
query.result: 31 You know how attentively I prepare myself 32 to listen; you know what is that 33 doubt that is to me so old a fast.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
34 Quasi falcone ch’esce del cappello, 35 move la testa e con l’ali si plaude, 36 voglia mostrando e faccendosi bello,
37 vid’ io farsi quel segno, che di laude 38 de la divina grazia era contesto, 39 con canti quai si sa chi là sù gaude.
query.result:
34 Almost like a falcon that comes out of the hood, 35 it moves the head and with the wings applauds, 36 showing desire and making itself beautiful,
37 I saw being made that sign, which of praise 38 of the divine grace was composed, 39 with songs as one knows who up there rejoices.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
40 Poi cominciò: «Colui che volse il sesto 41 a lo stremo del mondo, e dentro ad esso 42 distinse tanto occulto e manifesto,
43 non poté suo valor sì fare impresso 44 in tutto l’universo, che ’l suo verbo 45 non rimanesse in infinito eccesso.
query.result:
40 Then it began: “He who turned the sixth 41 to the extreme of the world, and within it 42 distinguished so much hidden and manifest,
43 could not make his power so impressed 44 in all the universe, that his word 45 did not remain in infinite excess.”

46 And this makes certain that the first proud one, 47 who was the sum of every creature, 48 for not awaiting light, fell unripe;
49 and from here it appears that every lesser nature 50 is a short receptacle for that good 51 which has no end and measures itself with itself.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
52 Dunque vostra veduta, che convene 53 esser alcun de’ raggi de la mente 54 di che tutte le cose son ripiene,
55 non pò da sua natura esser possente 56 tanto, che suo principio discerna 57 molto di là da quel che l’è parvente.
query.result:
52 Therefore your sight, which must be 53 some of the rays of the mind 54 with which all things are filled,
55 cannot by its nature be powerful 56 enough that it discerns its principle 57 much beyond what appears to it.

58 Therefore in the eternal justice 59 the sight that receives your world, 60 as an eye into the sea, enters within;
61 that, although from the shore it sees the bottom, 62 it does not see it in the open sea; and nevertheless 63 it is there, but conceals from it its being profound.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
64 Lume non è, se non vien dal sereno 65 che non si turba mai; anzi è tenèbra 66 od ombra de la carne o suo veleno.
query.result: 64 Light is not, if it does not come from the serene 65 that never clouds over; rather it is darkness 66 or shadow of the flesh or its poison.

Please translate each line literally into English.
76 Muore non battezzato e sanza fede: 77 ov’ è questa giustizia che ’l condanna? 78 ov’ è la colpa sua, se ei non crede?”.
query.result: 76 Dies unbaptized and without faith: 77 where is this justice that condemns him? 78 where is his fault, if he does not believe?

query.result:

91 As above the nest it turns itself 92 after it has fed the stork its young, 93 and how that which is pastured looks at it;

query.result:

103 it began again: «To this kingdom 104 never ascended who did not believe in Christ, 105 neither before nor after he was nailed to the wood».

106 But see: many cry “Christ, Christ!”, 107 who will be in judgment much less near 108 to him, than those who do not know Christ;
109 and such a Christian will harm the Ethiopian, 110 when the two companies will be separated, 111 one eternally rich and the other without resource.
